elements.content: We present the synthesis and structural and computational characterization of a heteroleptic dinuclear discrete complex [Cd2(μ1,3-NCS)2­(NCS)2­(LI)2]·4MeOH (1·4MeOH), where LI is the product of hydrolysis of one of the 2-PyC­(Ph) groups of the parent ligand 1,2-diphenyl-1,2-bis­((phenyl­(pyridin-2-yl)­methylene)­hydrazono)­ethane (L), fabricated from a mixture of Cd­(NO3)2­·4H2O and NH4NCS in methanol. An analogous procedure but in EtOH and iPrOH yielded crystals of the heteroleptic dinuclear discrete complex [Cd2(μ1,3-NCS)2­(NCS)2­(L)2] (2) and the polymeric complex of the composition [Cd3(NCS)6(L)] n (3). The bulky helical ligand L in the constituting CdII based synthons has been found to exhibit a quasi-aromatic Möbius features as revealed by the electron density of delocalized bonds method as well as the extended transition state coupled with natural orbitals for chemical valence calculations. It means that a transition metal induces π-electron delocalization solely in the ligand’s part; however, the d orbitals of CdII do not overlap with the π-system of L. It is further found that the donor/acceptor character of the substituents attached to L can tune the Möbius quasi-aromaticity. Finally, formation of the crystals is driven not only by the typical ionic/dative Cd–N bonds, but also by a number of noncovalent interactions starting from classic hydrogen bonds (N–H···N, N–H···O) going through π···π, C–H···π, to end up with nonintuitive and recently topical Lp···Lp interactions (Lp – lone pair): e.g., C···C, N···N, N···S, S···S as well as London dispersion dominated homopolar dihydrogen interactions C–H···H–C.

An analogous procedure but in EtOH and iPrOH yielded crystals of the heteroleptic dinuclear discrete complex [Cd2(μ1,3-NCS)2(NCS)2(L)2] (2) and the polymeric complex of the composition [Cd3(NCS)6(L)] n   (3). The bulky helical ligand L in the constituting CdII based synthons has been found to exhibit a quasi-aromatic Möbius features as revealed by the electron density of delocalized bonds method as well as the extended transition state coupled with natural orbitals for chemical valence calculations. It means that a transition metal induces π-electron delocalization solely in the ligand's part; however, the d orbitals of CdII do not overlap with the π-system of L. It is further found that the donor/acceptor character of the substituents attached to L can tune the Möbius quasi-aromaticity. Finally, formation of the crystals is driven not only by the typical ionic/dative Cd-N bonds, but also by a number of noncovalent interactions starting from classic hydrogen bonds (N-H⋅⋅⋅N, N-H⋅⋅⋅O) going through π⋅⋅⋅π, C-H⋅⋅⋅π, to end up with nonintuitive and recently topical Lp⋅⋅⋅Lp interactions (Lp - lone pair): e.g., C⋅⋅⋅C, N⋅⋅⋅N, N⋅⋅⋅S, S⋅⋅⋅S as well as London dispersion dominated homopolar dihydrogen interactions C-H⋅⋅⋅H-C.

elements.content: This work presents a solvent-driven formation and structural and spectroscopic characterizations of three novel CdII structures based on the sterically congested helical ligand 1,2-diphenyl-1,2-bis­((phenyl­(pyridin-2-yl)­methylene)­hydrazono)­ethane, which are proven (due to theoretical calculations based on the population based electron density of delocalized bonds method and charge and energy decomposition scheme extended transition state coupled with natural orbitals for chemical valence) to exhibit rare examples of quasi-aromatic Möbius-type objects stabilized primarily by London dispersion forces.
elements.clean_text: This work presents a solvent-driven formation and structural and spectroscopic characterizations of three novel CdII structures based on the sterically congested helical ligand 1,2-diphenyl-1,2-bis((phenyl(pyridin-2-yl)methylene)hydrazono)ethane, which are proven (due to theoretical calculations based on the population based electron density of delocalized bonds method and charge and energy decomposition scheme extended transition state coupled with natural orbitals for chemical valence) to exhibit rare examples of quasi-aromatic Möbius-type objects stabilized primarily by London dispersion forces.

elements.content: Coordination polymers based on transition metals have recently gained particular interest due to their practical use in various fields of chemistry, including for example, separation and adsorption sciences, catalysis, or optical applications. Recently, significant effort has been put into understanding of a mechanism leading to formation of such crystals and factors determining their architectures. Obviously, the nature of a solvent and a ligand type as well as their ability to create strong enough covalent-dative bonds together with a bunch of different types of noncovalent interactions must be crucial for a mechanism of self-assembling of metal based polymers. Furthermore, a choice of a suitable metal center is essential for a rational design of polymers exhibiting interesting architectures and useful properties. From this perspective applying the CdII atom is very promising. We have recently shown that using CdII jointly with NCS– anions and the ligands benzilbis­(pyridin-2-yl)­methylidenehydrazone and benzilbis­(acetylpyridin-2-yl)­methylidenehydrazone leads to the creation of rare examples of helical systems 1′ and 2′, respectively, which were shown for the first time to exhibit quasi-aromatic Möbius features (). It means that a transition metal induces the π-electron delocalization solely in the ligand’s part (). It is in contrast to the fully aromatic Möbius motif where the d orbital of a metal effectively overlaps with the ligand’s 2p orbitals (). It is to be added that the mentioned arrangements differ with respect to the most widely recognized in the literature Möbius aromatic topologies observed usually in cyclic hydrocarbons ().
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers based on transition metals have recently gained particular interest due to their practical use in various fields of chemistry, including for example, separation and adsorption sciences, catalysis, or optical applications. Recently, significant effort has been put into understanding of a mechanism leading to formation of such crystals and factors determining their architectures. Obviously, the nature of a solvent and a ligand type as well as their ability to create strong enough covalent-dative bonds together with a bunch of different types of noncovalent interactions must be crucial for a mechanism of self-assembling of metal based polymers. Furthermore, a choice of a suitable metal center is essential for a rational design of polymers exhibiting interesting architectures and useful properties. From this perspective applying the CdII atom is very promising. We have recently shown that using CdII jointly with NCS- anions and the ligands benzilbis(pyridin-2-yl)methylidenehydrazone and benzilbis(acetylpyridin-2-yl)methylidenehydrazone leads to the creation of rare examples of helical systems 1' and 2', respectively, which were shown for the first time to exhibit quasi-aromatic Möbius features (). It means that a transition metal induces the π-electron delocalization solely in the ligand's part (). It is in contrast to the fully aromatic Möbius motif where the d orbital of a metal effectively overlaps with the ligand's 2p orbitals (). It is to be added that the mentioned arrangements differ with respect to the most widely recognized in the literature Möbius aromatic topologies observed usually in cyclic hydrocarbons ().

(Bottom left) Quasi-aromatic partially twisted Möbius topology formed by Cd atom and the 2p orbitals of the ring −NH–NCH–CHNNH. (Bottom right) Typical planar Möbius aromatic arrangement formed by a d-transition metal orbital and the 2p on the unsaturated ring −CHCHCHCH–. Dashed line highlights the phase inversion.

(Bottom right) Typical planar Möbius aromatic arrangement formed by a d-transition metal orbital and the 2p on the unsaturated ring -CHCHCHCH-. Dashed line highlights the phase inversion.

elements.content: In our previous contribution, we have considered small units (R = H and Me, respectively) attached to the imine fragment. We have additionally noticed that the bulkiness of a ligand can be of significance not only for the thermodynamic stability, but also for alteration of quasi-aromaticity. To this end, in this work we have designed, synthesized, and fully characterized by quantum chemical computations novel extremely sterically congested quasi-aromatic CdII derivatives containing the N6 tetradentate helical ligand L with R = Ph units, derived from benzildihydrazone and 2-benzoylpyridine. Interestingly, by applying such a bulky ligand the solvent-driven formation of two dinuclear discrete and one-dimensional (1D) polymeric Cd­(NCS)2-based complexes is determined. To get comprehensive novel insight into factors that determine quasi-aromaticity of such systems, we have additionally considered computationally N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) substituents, namely, (CHNH)2C:, in the structure of the ligand L instead of two central phenyl rings. These NHC fragments exhibit both σ-donating and π-accepting properties directly attached to the metal-containing aromatic ring. The electronic structure, aromaticity, and physical nature of interactions in the newly considered systems are delineated by quantum chemical calculations.

elements.content: A reaction of the CdII salt with the tetradenate ligand L and NH4NCS gives rise to the formation of heteroleptic dinuclear discrete complex [Cd2(μ1,3-NCS)2­(NCS)2(LI)2]­·4MeOH (1·4MeOH), where LI is the product of hydrolysis of one of the 2-PyC­(Ph) groups of the parent ligand L (). It shall be emphasized that using the identical synthetic strategy but in EtOH and iPrOH produced crystals of the heteroleptic dinuclear discrete complex [Cd2(μ1,3-NCS)2­(NCS)2(L)2] (2) and the polymeric system of the composition [Cd3(NCS)6(L)] n (3), respectively (). In our previous work, no such solvent dependence behavior was observed. These systems were analyzed by FTIR spectroscopy, diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and DFT calculations; their compositions were established by elemental analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

A reaction of the CdII salt with the tetradenate ligand L and NH4NCS gives rise to the formation of heteroleptic dinuclear discrete complex [Cd2(μ1,3-NCS)2(NCS)2(LI)2]⋅4MeOH (1⋅4MeOH), where LI  is the product of hydrolysis of one of the 2-PyC(Ph) groups of the parent ligand L (). It shall be emphasized that using the identical synthetic strategy but in EtOH and iPrOH produced crystals of the heteroleptic dinuclear discrete complex [Cd2(μ1,3-NCS)2(NCS)2(L)2] (2) and the polymeric system of the composition [Cd3(NCS)6(L)] n   (3), respectively (). In our previous work, no such solvent dependence behavior was observed. These systems were analyzed by FTIR spectroscopy, diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and DFT calculations; their compositions were established by elemental analysis.

elements.content: The IR spectra of 1·4MeOH and 2 contain two bands at 2060 and 2095 cm–1 characteristic for the CN stretching of the NCS– anions (). The former band is in the region typical for the terminal N-bound NCS–, while the latter one is typical for the μ1,3-bridging NCS– ion. The FTIR spectrum of 3 exhibits at least three defined peaks at 2022, 2100, and 2125 cm–1, typical for the CN stretching of the μ1,3- and μ1,1,3-bridging NCS– anions (). The spectrum of 1·4MeOH further contains a broad band for the NH2 group and lattice MeOH molecules at 3100–3700 cm–1 ().

elements.content: Optical properties of L, 1·4MeOH, 2 and 3 were studied by diffuse reflectance spectroscopy in the form of pure solid powders. The obtained data were treated by the Kubelka–Munk function. The diffuse reflectance spectra exhibit bands up to ∼500 nm (), and the band gap energies were found to be 2.65 for L and 2.74, 2.75, and 2.68 eV for 1·4MeOH, 2 and 3, respectively.

The diffuse reflectance spectra exhibit bands up to ~500 nm (), and the band gap energies were found to be 2.65 for L and 2.74, 2.75, and 2.68 eV for 1⋅4MeOH, 2 and 3, respectively.

elements.content: As shown by the X-ray diffraction, 1·4MeOH and 3 crystallize in the P1̅ space group, while the structure of 2 was solved in the P21/c space group. The asymmetric unit of 1·4MeOH and 2 contains a half of the complex molecule [Cd­(μ1,3-NCS)­(NCS)­(L)] or [Cd­(μ1,3-NCS)­(NCS)­(LI)], respectively. The asymmetric unit of 1·4MeOH is further completed by two lattice methanol of which one is disordered over two positions with the ratio of about 67% and 33%. The asymmetric unit of 3 is constructed from one L, three symmetrically independent atoms of CdII and six NCS– anions. Notably, 2 was found to have a two component “flip” disorder at the μ1,3-NCS– ligands.
elements.clean_text: As shown by the X-ray diffraction, 1⋅4MeOH and 3 crystallize in the P1̅ space group, while the structure of 2 was solved in the P21/c space group. The asymmetric unit of 1⋅4MeOH and 2 contains a half of the complex molecule [Cd(μ1,3-NCS)(NCS)(L)] or [Cd(μ1,3-NCS)(NCS)(LI)], respectively. The asymmetric unit of 1⋅4MeOH is further completed by two lattice methanol of which one is disordered over two positions with the ratio of about 67% and 33%. The asymmetric unit of 3 is constructed from one L, three symmetrically independent atoms of CdII and six NCS- anions. Notably, 2 was found to have a two component "flip" disorder at the μ1,3-NCS- ligands.

elements.content: In the structures of 1·4MeOH and 2 the CdII centers are in a six- or seven-coordination geometry, respectively ( and ). In the latter structure the metal atoms are chelated by the two pyridyl-imine fragments of L, two N-atoms of one bridging and one terminal NCS– ligands, and one S-atom of the other bridging NCS– (). In the former structure, one of the pyridyl-imine fragments is replaced by the NH2 group, thus replacing two initial coordination sites by a single one (). The Cd–N bond distances in both 1·4MeOH and 2, corresponding to the N-atoms of LI and L, respectively, are in the range 2.353(2)–2.585(2) Å, maintaining that Cd–NPy ≈ Cd–NH2 < Cd–Nimine (Table S1 in the Supporting Information). The Cd–NCS bonds (2.287(3)­5–2.459(16) Å) are shorter than the Cd–N bonds within the corresponding chelate ligand. All the NCS– ligands in both structures are almost linear as evidenced from the N–C–S angle, which is av. 178°.
elements.clean_text: In the structures of 1⋅4MeOH and 2 the CdII centers are in a six- or seven-coordination geometry, respectively ( and ). In the latter structure the metal atoms are chelated by the two pyridyl-imine fragments of L, two N-atoms of one bridging and one terminal NCS- ligands, and one S-atom of the other bridging NCS- (). In the former structure, one of the pyridyl-imine fragments is replaced by the NH2 group, thus replacing two initial coordination sites by a single one (). The Cd-N bond distances in both 1⋅4MeOH and 2, corresponding to the N-atoms of LI  and L, respectively, are in the range 2.353(2)-2.585(2) Å, maintaining that Cd-NPy ~ Cd-NH2 < Cd-Nimine (Table S1 in the Supporting Information). The Cd-NCS bonds (2.287(3)5-2.459(16) Å) are shorter than the Cd-N bonds within the corresponding chelate ligand. All the NCS- ligands in both structures are almost linear as evidenced from the N-C-S angle, which is av. 178°.

elements.content: The CdN5S coordination polyhedron in 1·4MeOH was found to be a distorted octahedron (), while the CdN6S chromophore in 2 is best termed as a square face monocapped trigonal prism (). The latter finding is firmly supported by the corresponding face N–N–N bond angles, which are close to right angles (CCDC 1583995). Two N3 basal planes are almost parallel to each other with the corresponding dihedral angle of about 5.9°. The CdII ion is about 1.52 and 1.64 Å displaced from two basal planes.

elements.content: L and LI in 1·4MeOH and 2, respectively, adopt a twist helical conformation. It is associated with the torsion angle N–C­(Ph)–C­(Ph)–N of 80.8(3) and −84.0(4)°, respectively. The torsion angle between two pyridyl rings in 2 is of 68.07(19)°. The Cd···Cd separation within the dinuclear molecules of 1·4MeOH and 2 is about 5.85 and 6.02 Å, respectively.

The torsion angle between two pyridyl rings in 2 is of 68.07(19)°. The Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd separation within the dinuclear molecules of 1⋅4MeOH and 2 is about 5.85 and 6.02 Å, respectively.

elements.content: The crystal packing of 1·4MeOH is described primarily by the N–H···N hydrogen bonds formed by one of the NH2 H-atoms and the imine N-atom from the adjacent molecule (Table S2 in the Supporting Information). As a result of these interactions, a 1D polymeric zigzag-like chain is formed (). The remaining NH2 hydrogen atom is involved in the N–H···O hydrogen bonding with one of the crystallographic independent lattice methanol molecules (, Table S2 in the Supporting Information). The remaining disordered methanol is located in the solvent accessible voids (). The crystal packing of 1·4MeOH and 2 contains additional face-to-face π···π stacking between the aryl rings, and N–C–S···π in 1·4MeOH and C–H···π interactions in 2 (Tables S3 and S4 in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: The crystal packing of 1⋅4MeOH is described primarily by the N-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds formed by one of the NH2 H-atoms and the imine N-atom from the adjacent molecule (Table S2 in the Supporting Information). As a result of these interactions, a 1D polymeric zigzag-like chain is formed (). The remaining NH2 hydrogen atom is involved in the N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding with one of the crystallographic independent lattice methanol molecules (, Table S2 in the Supporting Information). The remaining disordered methanol is located in the solvent accessible voids (). The crystal packing of 1⋅4MeOH and 2 contains additional face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π stacking between the aryl rings, and N-C-S⋅⋅⋅π in 1⋅4MeOH and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions in 2 (Tables S3 and S4 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: In order to complement the above qualitative analyses, we have quantitatively described the nature of noncovalent interactions by the charge and energy decomposition scheme (ETS-NOCV) with DFT/BLYP-D3/TZP by means of the Amsterdam Density Functional (ADF) program. It was established that although the main bonding within a 1D chain of 1·4MeOH indeed originates from the two N–H···N hydrogen bonds (), the overall interaction energy exhibits an astonishingly low value of ΔE int = −51.92 kcal/mol. The main stabilizing factor is dispersion ΔE dispersion = −40.14 kcal/mol (47% of the overall stabilization defined as ΔE dispersion + ΔE orb + ΔE elstat) followed by the electrostatic ΔE elstat = −26.91 kcal/mol (32%) and charge delocalization ΔE orb = −18.17 kcal/mol (21%) terms. The dominance of the former component is due to the presence of supportive C–H···π, π···π, Lp···π (Lp = lone pair) and C–H···H–C interactions as can be noticed from the contour Δρorb (). Similar qualitative and quantitative ETS-NOCV characteristics can also be noted for 2 in which predominantly C–H···π and π···π interactions have been discovered ().

It was established that although the main bonding within a 1D chain of 1⋅4MeOH indeed originates from the two N-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds (), the overall interaction energy exhibits an astonishingly low value of ΔE int = -51.92 kcal/mol. The main stabilizing factor is dispersion ΔE dispersion = -40.14 kcal/mol (47% of the overall stabilization defined as ΔE dispersion + ΔE orb + ΔE elstat) followed by the electrostatic ΔE elstat = -26.91 kcal/mol (32%) and charge delocalization ΔE orb = -18.17 kcal/mol (21%) terms. The dominance of the former component is due to the presence of supportive C-H⋅⋅⋅π, π⋅⋅⋅π, Lp⋅⋅⋅π (Lp = lone pair) and C-H⋅⋅⋅H-C interactions as can be noticed from the contour Δρorb (). Similar qualitative and quantitative ETS-NOCV characteristics can also be noted for 2 in which predominantly C-H⋅⋅⋅π and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions have been discovered ().

elements.content: The ETS-NOCV calculations demonstrate that the methanol molecule in 1·4MeOH, which is bonded with the overall interaction energy ΔE int = −9.06 kcal/mol, forms not only typical hydrogen bonding N–H···O, but there are additional O–H···π and C–H···π interactions (). The latter observation is also supported by the overall deformation density contour, where a clearly outflow of the electron density is seen from both the O–H and C–H methanol bonds (). The latter noncovalent interactions lead to a significant dispersion stabilization ΔE dispersion = −7.40 kcal/mol (37% of the overall stabilization), which is of comparable importance to the still dominant electrostatic contribution ΔE elstat = −8.37 kcal/mol (42%) (). Charge delocalization demonstrating a significant covalent character of the N–H···O interaction has been shown to be the least important (21% of the overall stabilization).

The latter observation is also supported by the overall deformation density contour, where a clearly outflow of the electron density is seen from both the O-H and C-H methanol bonds (). The latter noncovalent interactions lead to a significant dispersion stabilization ΔE dispersion = -7.40 kcal/mol (37% of the overall stabilization), which is of comparable importance to the still dominant electrostatic contribution ΔE elstat = -8.37 kcal/mol (42%) (). Charge delocalization demonstrating a significant covalent character of the N-H⋅⋅⋅O interaction has been shown to be the least important (21% of the overall stabilization).

elements.content: The polymeric crystal structure of 3 is formed through chains of Cd­(NCS)2 components, ornamented with the Cd­(NCS)2L units (). The symmetrically independent CdII atoms, which fabricate the coordination backbone, were found to be in a distorted octahedral N4S2 or N2S4 coordination environment, respectively, with the Cd–N and Cd–S bond lengths of 2.249(2)–2.630(3) Å and 2.6782(8)–2.7690(8) Å, respectively (Table S1 in the Supporting Information). The other CdII atom, chelated by L, is in a six coordination geometry formed by the two pyridyl-imine fragments and two NCS– N-atoms, yielding a CdN6 trigonal prism (). Two N3 planes are practically parallel to each other with the corresponding dihedral angle of about 2.2°. The CdII ion is about 1.52 and 1.64 Å displaced from two basal planes. The Cd–N L bonds are about 2.34 and 2.44 Å, respectively, keeping that Cd–NPy < Cd–Nimine (Table S1 in the Supporting Information). The Cd–NCS bonds within the Cd­(NCS)2L unit are shorter than the bonds to the N-atoms within L (Table S1 in the Supporting Information). The N–C­(Ph)–C­(Ph)–N torsion angle is 76.5(3)°, while the analogous parameter for the C­(Ph)–N–N–C­(Ph) unit is 136.5(3) and 143.3(2)°.
elements.clean_text: The polymeric crystal structure of 3 is formed through chains of Cd(NCS)2 components, ornamented with the Cd(NCS)2L units (). The symmetrically independent CdII atoms, which fabricate the coordination backbone, were found to be in a distorted octahedral N4S2 or N2S4 coordination environment, respectively, with the Cd-N and Cd-S bond lengths of 2.249(2)-2.630(3) Å and 2.6782(8)-2.7690(8) Å, respectively (Table S1 in the Supporting Information). The other CdII atom, chelated by L, is in a six coordination geometry formed by the two pyridyl-imine fragments and two NCS- N-atoms, yielding a CdN6 trigonal prism (). Two N3 planes are practically parallel to each other with the corresponding dihedral angle of about 2.2°. The CdII ion is about 1.52 and 1.64 Å displaced from two basal planes. The Cd-N L  bonds are about 2.34 and 2.44 Å, respectively, keeping that Cd-NPy < Cd-Nimine (Table S1 in the Supporting Information). The Cd-NCS bonds within the Cd(NCS)2L unit are shorter than the bonds to the N-atoms within L (Table S1 in the Supporting Information). The N-C(Ph)-C(Ph)-N torsion angle is 76.5(3)°, while the analogous parameter for the C(Ph)-N-N-C(Ph) unit is 136.5(3) and 143.3(2)°.

elements.content: The shortest and longest Cd···Cd distances within the polymeric backbone are ∼3.82, 5.74, and 5.89 Å, while the shortest Cd···Cd separations between the symmetrically independent metal atoms of the polymeric backbone and the CdL metal center are ∼5.10, 6.03, and 6.47 Å (Table S1 in the Supporting Information). The NCS– anions in 3 exhibit either a μ1,3- or μ1,1,3-NCS coordination mode (). The packing of 3 is primarily described by the π···π stacking between the aryl rings and C–H···π interactions (Table S4 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: From the topological perspective, the 1D polymeric ribbon of 3 is built from the 3- and 6-connected CdII nodes (). Topological analysis discloses a unique trinodal 3,6,6-connected topology defined by the point symbol of (3·42)2(33·45·55·62)­(34·43·52·63·72·8). Notably, this topology has never been observed so far.

elements.content: In order to shed light on the electronic structure of 3 we have at first stage considered the cluster model built from the two Cd­(NCS)2(L) units (green and red colors) connected to the Cd2(NCS)4 fragment (blue color) through the Cd–SCN bonds (). Such a division pattern allows us to describe simultaneously the two Cd–SCN bonds in the ETS-NOCV approach. It is evident that they are ordinary dative connections, dominated by the ionic contribution (), where apart from the typical [S-Lp → Cd] donation and [Cd → π*­(SCN)] back-donation channels, the majority of electron density is accumulated in the Cd–S bonding regions, which indicates additionally significant covalency (). Interestingly, although the main electron density changes are expectedly within the two Cd–SCN bonds, significant electron density changes are noted at the distant surrounding the SCN units (). It is notable that both charge accumulation and depletion are seen at these ligands ().

Such a division pattern allows us to describe simultaneously the two Cd-SCN bonds in the ETS-NOCV approach. elements.content: In order to better understand this effect we have additionally considered a simplified Cd3(NCS)6 model and performed bonding analyses based on the ETS-NOCV (Figures S1 and S2 in the Supporting Information), QTAIM, and NCI based index (). It was found that between the closely packed NCS units various recently topical noncovalent interactions (C···C, N···N, S···S, and N···S) exist (colored by the green discs of reduced density gradient) in addition to Cd–S/N bonds illuminated by the deep blue regions of the NCI contour (, and Figures S1 and S2 in the Supporting Information). It is very interesting since Lp–Lp (lone pair) interactions are often repulsive. We have additionally confirmed due to computationally demanding IQA energy decomposition performed at the MP2/def2-tzvp level, that the covalent-dative Cd–S bond energy is −63.7 kcal/mol, whereas the example N···S interaction energy is found to be −12.1 kcal/mol (). Future in-depth studies are planned in order to delineate and quantify factors contributing to these intriguing Lp–Lp (lone pair) interactions which influence the unusual topology of crystal 3.

elements.content: Finally, we shed light on the aromaticity of the synthesized systems using the recently developed electron density of delocalized bonds (EDDB) method. In this method the number of electrons, in a sense of population quantity, delocalized through conjugated bonds is determined. Additionally, the EDDB function can be visualized giving rise to a qualitative representation of the electron delocalization. It has been demonstrated that it works well for various systems, including transition metal complexes. Brief overview of the EDDB method is given in the Supporting Information.

It has been demonstrated that it works well for various systems, including transition metal complexes. Brief overview of the EDDB method is given in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: We focused our attention on the seven-membered rings (7-MR) containing the metal and a twisted 1,1′-(1,2-ethenediyl)­bis-diazene (BDA) fragment (abbreviated as BDA-Cd) since they have been shown to exhibit a new type of quasi-aromatic Möbius motif in which resonance stabilization through the BDA ligand is induced by the metal. However, the metal itself does not participate in the π-conjugation, and thus it is quite difficult to make a direct comparison with typical single (or even multiple) half-twisted Möbius π-conjugation topologies found, e.g., in the expanded porphyrins. Additionally, a quantitative study of resonance effects in larger units is very difficult in practice (Figures S3–S5, and cg8b01569_si_002.mpg, cg8b01569_si_003.mpg, and cg8b01569_si_004.mpg video files in the Supporting Information). Accordingly, we have considered the BDA-Cd models. We have determined herein that ∼3 |e| in 1 and ∼3.3 |e| in 2 and 3 are delocalized through the twisted metallacyclic units, where the metal atom is clearly not involved (). It is the comparable trend to our previous findings for 1′ and 2′, despite the presence of the two additional Ph units (). The electron delocalization efficiency (the EDDB population divided by the total number of π-electrons) is ∼40%, given the fact that the ligand carries 4 π-bonds, which is similar to Hückel-like (4n + 2) heteroaromatic species such as pyrrole (∼55%) or thiophene (∼40%). This clearly proves quasi-aromaticity of the Möbius type. We have additionally found from ETS-NOCV that the total π-bonding in L is −92.03 kcal/mol (Figure S6 in the Supporting Information). The corresponding estimation for benzene is quite comparable, −108.7 kcal/mol (Figure S6 in the Supporting Information). Other metallabenzenes exhibit similar strength of π-bonding.

elements.content: Due to striking similarity of the delocalization degree for 1–3 and the previously studied 1′, 2′ (in spite of using another sets of ligands containing Ph vs H, Me), we have envisioned, that the electronic nature of the functional groups attached to the central part of the chelating ligands might be of crucial importance for tuning the quasi-aromaticity. Accordingly, we have decided to briefly analyze computationally the novel derivative 4, which is viable experimentally, with N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC), (CHNH)2C:, in the structure of the ligand L instead of two central phenyl rings (). Notably, NHC is known to be able to significantly perturb both σ and π-contributions to a chemical bond. Indeed, such a ligand exhibits a dramatic influence on the quasi-aromaticity – ∼6.7 |e| are now delocalized within the 7-MR metallacyclic unit what gives the delocalization efficiency by ∼84% ().

Accordingly, we have decided to briefly analyze computationally the novel derivative 4, which is viable experimentally, with N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC), (CHNH)2C:, in the structure of the ligand L instead of two central phenyl rings (). Notably, NHC is known to be able to significantly perturb both σ and π-contributions to a chemical bond. Indeed, such a ligand exhibits a dramatic influence on the quasi-aromaticity - ~6.7 |e| are now delocalized within the 7-MR metallacyclic unit what gives the delocalization efficiency by ~84% ().

elements.content: Finally, it is useful to also consider aromaticity in the fully optimized unit with four H-atoms instead of four phenyl rings in the structure of L. Here, interestingly, the delocalization efficiency on the π-conjugated ligand fragment is ∼70%, despite the fact that it is less twisted than their substituted derivatives. In principle, this is not be surprising since Möbius-type aromaticity is known to be not only restricted to twisted cyclic units.

elements.content: It is to be referenced that Solà and co-workers have recently published a comprehensive and critical review on the applicability of various aromaticity descriptors and mentioned that reliable probing of aromaticity in transition metal systems is still very challenging. To this end we have applied herein the EDDB and ETS-NOCV methods which have been proven to provide reliable data even for transition metal systems. A notable reduction of aromaticity by ∼0.3 |e| in the 7-MR fragment in 1 is due to the protonation of the nitrogen atom (). Although in the typical (hetero)­aromatic examples such protonation usually completely destroys aromaticity, the lone pair on the nitrogen atom in the 7-MR fragment in 1 still notably contributes to the resonance (). When considering nonbulky models (the phenyl rings are substituted by hydrogen atoms) the resonance is notably less efficient, 2.4–2.7 |e| in 1–3 and 4.3 |e| in 4, which proves the importance of bulky (London dispersion) units in the amplification of delocalization ().

When considering nonbulky models (the phenyl rings are substituted by hydrogen atoms) the resonance is notably less efficient, 2.4-2.7 |e| in 1-3 and 4.3 |e| in 4, which proves the importance of bulky (London dispersion) units in the amplification of delocalization ().

elements.content: Finally, in the light of the fact that Cd atoms do not participate in π-delocalization, we have decided to perform periodic DFT/BAND/HS06 calculations for 1 and 3 to determine whether the obtained valence and conduction bands contain significant contributions from Cd atoms as is the case for other Cd-based polymers. We have determined, in reasonable agreement with the experiment, that 3 indeed exhibits a lower band gap (∼2.5 eV) as compared with 1 (∼3.0 eV) (Figures S7 and S8 in the Supporting Information). Furthermore, the valence and conduction bands hardly contain Cd contributions which is fully in line with the quasi-aromaticity delineated in the previous paragraphs. It could also explain lack of solid-state emission since other Cd polymers containing for example 1,2-bis­(benzotriazol-1-yl)­ethane are luminescent due to MLCT processes.

We have determined, in reasonable agreement with the experiment, that 3 indeed exhibits a lower band gap (~2.5 eV) as compared with 1 (~3.0 eV) (Figures S7 and S8 in the Supporting Information). elements.content:
All substances and solvents were commercially accessible and applied without additional purification.

Physical Measurements

FTIR were documented on a Bruker Tensor 27 FTIR devise, whereas diffuse reflectance spectra with a Analytik Jena SPECORD 200 spectrometer [the reference is polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE)]. Bands were determined on pure solids to exclude matrix effects. Possible distortions in the Kubelka–Munk spectra that could outcome from the study of pure species have not been considered since no comparison with absorption spectra was required. Microanalyses were done by means of ElementarVario EL III analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All substances and solvents were commercially accessible and applied without additional purification.

Physical Measurements

FTIR were documented on a Bruker Tensor 27 FTIR devise, whereas diffuse reflectance spectra with a Analytik Jena SPECORD 200 spectrometer [the reference is polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE)]. Bands were determined on pure solids to exclude matrix effects. Possible distortions in the Kubelka-Munk spectra that could outcome from the study of pure species have not been considered since no comparison with absorption spectra was required. Microanalyses were done by means of ElementarVario EL III analyzer.

elements.content: The natural orbitals for chemical valence (NOCV) originate from the following eigenvalue equation: Δ P C i = v i C i where ΔP is a difference between a molecular density matrix and the corresponding matrices for fragments expressed in Löwdin representation. It was shown that NOCVs decompose the differential density Δρ into NOCV contributions (Δρk ): Δ ρ ( r ) = ∑ k = 1 M / 2 V k [ − ψ − k 2 ( r ) + ψ k 2 ( r ) ] = ∑ k = 1 M / 2 Δ ρ k ( r ) where νk and M are the NOCV eigenvalues and the number of basis functions, respectively. Visual examination of Δρk determines the nature of a given contribution. These terms are augmented by the energetic estimates, ΔE orb(k) within the ETS-NOCV scheme. In the ETS method the total bonding energy, ΔE int, between interacting fragments, exhibiting the geometry as in the combined complex, is divided into three components: ΔE total = ΔE elstat + ΔE Pauli + ΔE orb. The first term, ΔE elstat, shown the classical electrostatic force between subunits. The second term, ΔE Pauli, is due to repulsive Pauli interaction, whereas the last ΔE orb, represents charge delocalization due to bond creation. In the ETS-NOCV approach ΔE orb is written in terms of NOCV’s eigenvalues (vk ) as Δ E o r b = ∑ k Δ E o r b ( k ) = ∑ k = 1 M / 2 v k [ − F − k , − k T S + F k , k T S ] where F i, i TS are diagonal KS energy matrix elements. The ETS-NOCV analysis was done by the (ADF) package.

elements.content: The electron density of delocalized bonds (EDDB) has recently been proposed to facilitate visualization and quantitative analysis of local and global aromaticity as well as different resonance effects in a wide range of molecular systems from small monocyclic aromatics to nanoscopic-size systems like fullerenes, graphene petals, or carbon nanotubes. EDDB represents the electron density layer associated with electrons delocalized through the system of conjugated bonds (n-center-m-electron bonds, aromatic rings and cages, metalloaromatics, etc.). Formally, the EDDB­(r) function is defined within the representation of Weinhold’s natural atomic orbitals (NAO), EDDB ( r ) = ∑ μ , ν χ μ † ( r ) D μ ν DB χ ν ( r ) , where the corresponding DB-density matrix reads D DB = 1 2 P [ ∑ α , β ≠ α Ω C α β ε α β λ α β 2 C α β † ] P . In the latter equation P is the reduced one-electron density matrix, C αβ collects the LCNAO coefficients of the co-called two-center bond-order orbitals (2cBO), λ αβ and ε αβ are diagonal matrices of the 2cBO occupation numbers and the bond-conjugation (scaling) factors, respectively, while Ω represents a set of all the possible atomic pairs in a molecule. A more in-depth description and formal definitions of these quantities can be found in the original works refs , but it has to be emphasized here that the trace of EDDB­(r) hasin contrast to other delocalization/aromaticity quantifiersvery intuitive interpretation of the population of electrons delocalized (in a multicenter sense) through the system of conjugated bonds, Ω.

elements.content:
Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.154 g, 0.5 mmol), NH4NCS (0.076 g, 1 mmol), and L (0.284 g, 0.5 mmol) were put into a tube. MeOH, EtOH, or iPrOH (15 mL) was slowly added to fill the arms. The tube was sealed and immersed in an oil bath at 60 °C, whereas the branched part was preserved at ambient temperature. The right X-ray crystals were produced during the next days in the cooler arm and were filtered off. The details of X-ray analyses were provided in the Supporting Information.

4MeOH Colorless plate-like crystals. Yield: 0.275 g (79%). Anal. Calc. for C60H58Cd2N14O4S4 (1392.27) (%): C 51.76, H 4.20, and N 14.08; found: C 51.64, H 4.33, and N 14.18.

Yellow cube-like crystals. Yield: 0.355 g (89%). Anal. Calc. for C80H56Cd2N16S4 (1594.49) (%): C 60.26, H 3.54, and N 14.06; found: C 60.49, H 3.66, and N 13.89.

Pale yellow cube-like crystals. Yield: 0.176 g (84%). Anal. Calc. for C44H28Cd3N12S6 (1254.38) (%): C 42.13, H 2.25, and N 13.40; found: C 42.21, H 2.17, and N 13.33.

Synthesis of Complexes and X-ray Analyses

Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.154 g, 0.5 mmol), NH4NCS (0.076 g, 1 mmol), and L (0.284 g, 0.5 mmol) were put into a tube. MeOH, EtOH, or iPrOH (15 mL) was slowly added to fill the arms. The tube was sealed and immersed in an oil bath at 60 °C, whereas the branched part was preserved at ambient temperature. In summary, we have designed, synthesized, and fully characterized by quantum chemical computations novel heteroleptic dinuclear discrete complex [Cd2(μ1,3-NCS)2­(NCS)2(LI)2]­·4MeOH (1·4MeOH), where LI is the product of hydrolysis of one of the 2-PyC­(Ph) groups of the parent ligand 1,2-diphenyl-1,2-bis­((phenyl­(pyridin-2-yl)­methylene)­hydrazono)­ethane (L), fabricated from a mixture of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O and NH4NCS in methanol. An analogous experiment but in EtOH and iPrOH produced crystals of the heteroleptic dinuclear discrete complex [Cd2(μ1,3-NCS)2­(NCS)2(L)2] (2) and the polymeric complex of the composition [Cd3(NCS)6(L)] n (3). The formation of three significantly different structures is entirely determined by the solvent type. Thus, diverse solvents (MeOH, EtOH, and iPrOH) act as structure-directing species, adjusted by their size and shape, for the Cd­(NCS)2L-system.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have designed, synthesized, and fully characterized by quantum chemical computations novel heteroleptic dinuclear discrete complex [Cd2(μ1,3-NCS)2(NCS)2(LI)2]⋅4MeOH (1⋅4MeOH), where LI  is the product of hydrolysis of one of the 2-PyC(Ph) groups of the parent ligand 1,2-diphenyl-1,2-bis((phenyl(pyridin-2-yl)methylene)hydrazono)ethane (L), fabricated from a mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O and NH4NCS in methanol. An analogous experiment but in EtOH and iPrOH produced crystals of the heteroleptic dinuclear discrete complex [Cd2(μ1,3-NCS)2(NCS)2(L)2] (2) and the polymeric complex of the composition [Cd3(NCS)6(L)] n   (3). The formation of three significantly different structures is entirely determined by the solvent type. Thus, diverse solvents (MeOH, EtOH, and iPrOH) act as structure-directing species, adjusted by their size and shape, for the Cd(NCS)2L-system.

elements.content: In line with the X-ray diffraction, 3 is formed due to Cd­(NCS)2 fragments situated along the crystallographic a axis which are further furnished with Cd­(NCS)2L units. From the topological perspective, the 1D polymeric ribbon of 3 is built from the 3- and 6-connected CdII nodes. Topological analysis discloses a unique trinodal 3,6,6-connected coordination characterized by point group (3·42)2­(33·45·55·62)­(34·43·52·63·72·8).
elements.clean_text: In line with the X-ray diffraction, 3 is formed due to Cd(NCS)2 fragments situated along the crystallographic a axis which are further furnished with Cd(NCS)2L units. From the topological perspective, the 1D polymeric ribbon of 3 is built from the 3- and 6-connected CdII nodes. Topological analysis discloses a unique trinodal 3,6,6-connected coordination characterized by point group (3⋅42)2(33⋅45⋅55⋅62)(34⋅43⋅52⋅63⋅72⋅8).

elements.content: It has been determined by theoretical calculations stemming from the ETS-NOCV and EDDB population based methods that the bulky helical ligand L in the isolated complexes exhibits a rare example of quasi-aromatic Möbius motif, where the CdII atom does not directly participate in delocalization. It has been found that the substituents attached to L, which exhibit both strong σ-donating and π-accepting properties, significantly enhance the resonance efficiency from ∼40% for the phenyl-containing derivatives up to ∼84% for the NHC-containing ligand.

It has been found that the substituents attached to L, which exhibit both strong σ-donating and π-accepting properties, significantly enhance the resonance efficiency from ~40% for the phenyl-containing derivatives up to ~84% for the NHC-containing ligand.

elements.content: The obtained crystals are proven to be stabilized by ionic and dative Cd–N bonds as well as by a number of noncovalent interactions starting from classical hydrogen bonds (N–H···N, N–H···O) going through π···π, C–H···π, to end up with less understood σ/π-hole families (N···N, N···S, S···S) as well as by nonintuitive recently topical dispersion dominated homopolar dihydrogen interactions C–H···H–C which are often important in sterically crowded species.
elements.clean_text: The obtained crystals are proven to be stabilized by ionic and dative Cd-N bonds as well as by a number of noncovalent interactions starting from classical hydrogen bonds (N-H⋅⋅⋅N, N-H⋅⋅⋅O) going through π⋅⋅⋅π, C-H⋅⋅⋅π, to end up with less understood σ/π-hole families (N⋅⋅⋅N, N⋅⋅⋅S, S⋅⋅⋅S) as well as by nonintuitive recently topical dispersion dominated homopolar dihydrogen interactions C-H⋅⋅⋅H-C which are often important in sterically crowded species.

Optical properties of L, 1·4MeOH, 2 and 3 were studied by diffuse reflectance spectroscopy in the form of pure solid powders. The obtained data were treated by the Kubelka–Munk function. The diffuse reflectance spectra exhibit bands up to ∼500 nm (), and the band gap energies were found to be 2.65 for L and 2.74, 2.75, and 2.68 eV for 1·4MeOH, 2 and 3, respectively.
